unexpectedGuest.name: unexpectedGuest
unexpectedGuest.title: The Unexpected Guest
descriptions: Art, writing and thinking on hospitality
Edited by Sally Tallant and Paul Domela
With a text by Lorenzo Fusi

Hospitality is the welcome we extend to strangers, an attitude and a code of conduct, and a metaphor encompassing issues of the body, territory, politics, ecology, commerce and the hosting of data. It is the point where hostility becomes friendship, where the unknown becomes the familiar, and where the outside becomes the inside. But it also about the exercise of power: the power to accommodate or to exclude, the power to impose oneself on the other, and the power to outstay’s one’s welcome. In an age of unprecedented movement of both people and knowledge, different cultures of hospitality confront one another as never before.

Published on the occasion of the 7th Liverpool Biennial, The Unexpected Guest welcomes and gives home to an array of artists, writers and thinkers from the four corners of the globe. It is not intended as a catalogue of the exhibition, nor is it simply a reader on the subject. Instead, it is a complex anthology of newly commissioned writing, artists’ exhibitions and creative texts that explore one of the most pressing issues of our time.

Artists have been invited to make a contribution that reflects upon a particular aspect of hospitality, or to invite a guest to occupy their space. In an extraordinary collection of new writing, Kenneth Goldsmith has invited twenty-nine fellow poets to compose works on two key areas of relevance to the subject: technology and geography. Commissioned essays by leading scholars from Africa, the Americas, Europe and Asia consider hospitality from multiple perspectives, including colonial history, spatial politics and the ethics of the host–guest relationship.
Together, this rich compilation of art, writing and thinking not only deepens our understanding of hospitality in the twenty-first century, it also offers possibilities for the future.
Sally Tallant is the director of the Liverpool Biennial. Paul Domela is programme director of the Liverpool Biennial. Lorenzo Fusi is the curator of 'The Unexpected Guest'.

giasson_je_suis_un_veritable_artiste.name: giasson_je_suis_un_veritable_artiste
giasson_je_suis_un_veritable_artiste.title: Je suis un véritable artiste
descriptions: In 1972, the conceptual artist Keith Arnatt have been photographed as a sandwich man, holding a placard which reads: I'M A REAL ARTIST to create his Trouser-Word Piece. This photograph was accompanied by a philosophical text that questioned the term "real". However, Arnatt’s piece remained ambiguous: Was it simply tautological (an artist says that he is an artist within a work of art...) or was it ironic? Forty years after the creation of Trouser-Word Piece and in a similar spirit, my poem JE SUIS UN VÉRITABLE ARTISTE questions the possibility of having a “real”/stable identity.

gagaPortrait.name: gagaPortrait
gagaPortrait.title: Gaga: A Portrait
descriptions: Conceptual poem compelling lyrics in which the pop star Lady Gaga says her own name. Released for the first time on the site Gaga Stigmata on February 19, 2012. It is forthcoming in the anthology Gaga Stigmata: ¡Pop! ¡Culture! ¡Art! ¡Criticism! ¡Revolution!

tweetEngels.name: tweetEngels
tweetEngels.title: Tweet From Engels
descriptions: In early 2011, poet Philip Davenport and artist Lois Blackburn met with many homeless people in Manchester, England and asked them to describe their lives. Some of this writing and talking was gathered into a long, many-voiced poem. Tweet from Engels was first launched as a twitter feed and is now this book.
tweetEngels.authors: Philip Davenport, Lois Blackburn, Steve Giasson et al.

tiffany_co_poems.name: tiffany_co_poems
tiffany_co_poems.title: Tiffany & Co.Poems
descriptions: Poems based on the famous Tiffany & Co. jewelry catalogs. The selected catalogs correspond to the months of Occupy Wall Street.

someGasoline.name: someGasoline
someGasoline.title: Some Gasoline Prices
descriptions: Poem rifting, like many others, on Ed Ruscha's famous book Twentysix Gasoline Stations (1963), but focusing this time on the prices of gasoline in 2011.
"Spark and it's like gasoline/I start burning like a machine/My heart only runs on supreme/So hot, give me your gasoline "(Britney Spears)
". . . it comes, I tell you, immense with gasolined rags/and bits of wire and old bent nails, a dark arriviste,/from a dark river within."(Gregory Corso, How Poetry Comes to Me, page 1369)

passport.name: passport
passport.title: (passport)
descriptions: "Language is not transparent." -Mel Bochner

whiteSquares.title: White Squares

o.name: o
o.title: O
descriptions: Poem consisting only of O’s.
"There is no such thing as a good painting about nothing." - Adolph Gottlieb and Mark Rothko, 1947"There is no such thing as a good painting about something." -Ad Reinhardt, 1947

bazookaJoe2.title: Bazooka Joe © (2<sup>nd</sup> edition)
descriptions: Micro-stories based on the (often patriotic, sexist and racist) jokes coming with Bazooka Joe bubble gums.

jokes_after_richard_prince.title: Jokes (After Richard Prince)
descriptions: Poem and / or book of jokes in which Giasson appropriates Richard Prince’s (often disturbing) Jokes Paintings.

eleven.name: eleven
descriptions: 11 is a poem of 2637 pages compiling all the comments about a video on YouTube surrounding the terrorist attack against the World Trade Center the Sept. 11, 2001.
http://www.ubu.com/contemp/giasson/index.html

fitterman_directions.name: fitterman_directions
fitterman_directions.title: Directions
descriptions: Poem compiling all the possible itineraries (by foot, by bus, by jet, etc.) between Mr. Fitterman’s apartment in NYC and  Giasson’s apartment in Montreal.
fitterman_directions.otherDate: Presented by Kenneth Goldsmith at the 7th Biennial Liverpool from 15 September to 25 November 2012.

psychosis.name: psychosis
psychosis.title: Psychosis
descriptions: Poem of 44 pages compiling all the comments surrounding a video on YouTube of the famous shower scene in Alfred Hitchcock's Psycho.

this_is_visual_poetry.name: this_is_visual_poetry
this_is_visual_poetry.title: This is Visual Poetry
descriptions: Poem composed of stickers found in the streets of New York City.
